content.body:

content.formatted_body:
In reply to @annevk:matrix.org
jarhar: why does none of the selectedcontent impl logic check for the button element being there?
I think because you can put it in your picker as well? Not just within the button.

content.body: Luke Warlow: not per its content model.
content.formatted_body: Luke Warlow: not per its content model.

content.body: sure we can make it check for the button if you want
i also plan to make the selectedcontent element work outside of the select element in the future though for other cases where you can build your own popover with a select in it
I was mainly looking for motivation. It probably does not give much benefit to enforce it

Hi, I have a question about focus. Iâ€™m having a bit of a hard time following the spec. With a page like this: ```html
#target
go to #target ``` Or like this: ```html ``` If I click the link `go to #target` and then press `Shift+Tab`, where should the focus go according to the spec?
content.formatted_body:
Hi,
I have a question about focus. Iâ€™m having a bit of a hard time following the spec.

With a page like this:

<body>
	<div id="target">#target</div>
	<a href="#target">go to #target</a>
</body>

Or like this:

<body>
	<button>before</button>
	<iframe>
		<div id="target">#target</div>
		<a href="#target">go to #target</a>
	</iframe>
	<button>after</button>
</body>

If I click the link go to #target and then press Shift+Tab, where should the focus go according to the spec?

content.body: sb3nder: based on https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/browsing-the-web.html#scroll-to-the-fragment-identifier the document's viewport gets focus, but I don't think it's strictly defined where that sits in the tab order (and to some extent that's all up to implementations as it's UI)
content.formatted_body: sb3nder: based on https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/browsing-the-web.html#scroll-to-the-fragment-identifier the document's viewport gets focus, but I don't think it's strictly defined where that sits in the tab order (and to some extent that's all up to implementations as it's UI)

content.body: sb3nder: that is, the document's viewport gets focus when you follow the link as the div is not a focusable area (I'm assuming it's not scrollable here)
content.formatted_body: sb3nder: that is, the document's viewport gets focus when you follow the link as the div is not a focusable area (I'm assuming it's not scrollable here)

content.body:
I get lost in this part:
> 1. If new focus target is not a focusable area, then set new focus target to the result of getting the focusable area for new focus target, given focus trigger if it was passed.

Wouldn't `get the focusable area` set `new focus target` to null?
content.formatted_body:
I get lost in this part:

  1. If new focus target is not a focusable area, then set new focus target to the result of getting the focusable area for new focus target, given focus trigger if it was passed.

Wouldn't get the focusable area set new focus target to null?

content.body: ah! not this part, my bad, I forgot witch it was.
